title: Physical Affection Styles
description: Discover how you each like to give and receive physical affection.

questions.text: When it comes to physical affection, I naturally tend to...
choices: Give it freely throughout the day
Save it for meaningful moments
Match my partner's energy
Need to feel emotionally connected first

therapeutic.rationale: Affection-giving patterns reveal attachment style and love expression. Frequent givers show love through constant touch; moment-savers create significance; matchers adapt; connection-needers link physical and emotional. Partners often have different patterns.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The frequent giver may feel rejected by the moment-saver; the moment-saver may feel overwhelmed by constant touch. Neither is wrong—share what touch means to you.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared affection patterns create natural harmony. You'll instinctively give what your partner wants.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you naturally express affection? Where did you learn that pattern?

questions.text: The type of physical touch that makes me feel most loved is...
choices: Gentle, tender touches (hand-holding, caressing)
Close contact (cuddling, being held)
Playful touch (tickling, wrestling, playfulness)
Passionate touch (kissing, intimacy)

therapeutic.rationale: Touch preferences vary widely. Gentle-touch lovers feel loved through tenderness; close-contact lovers need proximity; playful-touch lovers connect through fun; passionate-touch lovers feel loved through desire. Knowing your partner's language matters.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different touch preferences may leave one partner feeling unloved despite effort. The gentle-toucher may not realize their partner needs more passion; the passion-lover may not realize their partner needs more tenderness.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared touch preference makes connection easier. You naturally speak the same physical language.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What kind of touch makes you feel most loved and connected? Be specific.

questions.text: In terms of how much physical affection I need, I'd say...
choices: A lot—I'm very physically oriented
A moderate amount—quality over quantity
It varies depending on my mood and stress
Less than most—I show love other ways

therapeutic.rationale: Affection needs vary by person and aren't right or wrong. High-need partners feel disconnected without regular touch; moderate-need partners prioritize meaning; variable-need partners fluctuate; low-need partners connect differently. Mismatched needs cause pain.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The high-need partner may feel rejected; the low-need partner may feel pressured. Neither is wrong—find your compromise zone and check in regularly.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched affection needs prevent a common relationship pain point. You'll naturally satisfy each other.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How much physical affection do you need to feel connected? Has that changed over time?

questions.text: When I'm stressed or upset, physical affection usually...
choices: Helps me feel better and more grounded
Feels like too much—I need space first
Depends on what I'm stressed about
Is welcome if I initiate it

therapeutic.rationale: How we receive touch during stress reveals coping patterns. Touch-soothers are calmed by contact; space-needers are overwhelmed; context-dependers vary; initiators need control. Misreading your partner's stress-touch needs backfires.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The touch-soother may feel rejected when their stressed partner pulls away; the space-needer may feel smothered by comfort attempts. Ask: 'Do you want me close right now?'
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared stress-touch preferences make comforting each other intuitive.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you're really stressed, does touch help or feel like too much? What do you need?

questions.text: Public displays of affection make me feel...
choices: Happy—I like showing we're together
Slightly uncomfortable—I prefer privacy
Fine with small gestures, not big ones
Depends on the setting and who's around

therapeutic.rationale: PDA comfort reveals personality and cultural background. PDA-lovers feel proud; private types feel exposed; moderate types have limits; context-readers adapt. Mismatched comfort creates awkward moments and hurt feelings.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The PDA-lover may feel their private partner is ashamed; the private partner may feel the PDA-lover is showing off. Neither is true—it's just comfort level. Find your shared zone.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared PDA comfort prevents public awkwardness. You'll naturally match in social settings.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel about affection in public? Where does that comfort level come from?
